questions.text: A 4-year-old boy presented with painful urination, obstructive symptoms, and severe urgency and straining. Cystoscopy reveals the presence of polypoidal mass in the bladder. Excision of the mass was done and sent for histopathological examination. What is the most likely diagnosis based on the histopathological examination of the bladder biopsy?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The given clinical scenario along with histopathological image showing small round blue cells is suggestive of rhabdomyosarcoma of the bladder.

  • Embryonal rhabdomyosarcoma is the most common type of bladder sarcoma seen during infancy and childhood.
  • Rhabdomyosarcoma is a malignant tumor of mesenchymal origin that exhibits skeletal muscle differentiation.
  • It has four recognized subtypes: embryonal, alveolar, pleomorphic, and spindle cell/sclerosing.
  • Rhabdomyosarcoma is the most common soft tissue sarcoma in children and adolescents, particularly the embryonal and alveolar types. While pleomorphic RMS is seen in adults, the spindle cell/sclerosing type can affect all age groups.
  • Pediatric rhabdomyosarcoma frequently occurs in regions without typical skeletal muscle, such as the genitourinary tract, head and neck, suggesting it originates from undifferentiated mesenchymal stem cells.
  • Embryonal RMS typically presents as a soft, gray, infiltrative mass composed of primitive round and spindle cells in a myxoid background, often showing cross-striations in rhabdomyoblasts.
  • A variant known as sarcoma botryoides arises in hollow viscera like the bladder and vagina, forming grape-like polypoid masses.
  • Alveolar rhabdomyosarcoma is marked by fibrous septa dividing uniform, round tumor cells into nests, resembling pulmonary alveoli.
  • Pleomorphic rhabdomyosarcoma contains bizarre, eosinophilic, often multinucleated tumor cells requiring immunohistochemistry (e.g., myogenin) to confirm diagnosis.
  • Spindle cell/sclerosing rhabdomyosarcoma shows fascicles or storiform arrangements of spindle cells, with occasional rhabdomyoblasts and dense sclerotic stroma, more common in adults.

Explanations of other options:

Leiomyoma (Option A): Leiomyoma is the most frequently occurring benign mesenchymal tumor in the bladder, though such tumors overall are quite rare. They typically present as well-circumscribed, encapsulated masses that are located within the bladder wall (intramural or submucosal). Morphologically, these tumors appear oval to spherical in shape and can reach several centimeters in diameter.

Interstitial cystitis (Option C): Interstitial cystitis is a chronic bladder condition of unknown cause, predominantly affecting women. It presents as pelvic pain or pressure perceived to be linked to the bladder, along with urinary symptoms such as frequency, urgency, hematuria, and dysuria lasting over six weeks without any identifiable infection. Cystoscopy may show mucosal fissures and pinpoint hemorrhages called glomerulations. Histologically, there are no specific findings, but increased mast cells are often noted in the submucosa, though their role is unclear. Some patients develop chronic mucosal ulcers (Hunner ulcers), marking the late ulcerative stage, and in advanced cases, fibrosis can cause the bladder to contract.

Malakoplakia (Option D): Malakoplakia is a unique chronic inflammatory disorder that arises due to impaired phagocytic function, typically in response to long-standing bacterial infections, most often caused by E. coli.. It tends to occur more frequently in immunocompromised individuals, including those who have undergone renal transplantation.On cystoscopic examination, it presents as soft, slightly elevated yellow plaques measuring approximately 3 to 4 cm. Histologically, the lesion is made up of clusters of large foamy macrophages, sometimes accompanied by multinucleated giant cells and lymphocytes. A hallmark feature is the presence of Michaelis-Gutmann bodies which are laminated, calcified structures found within enlarged lysosomes of macrophages.

questions.text: A 27-year-old female presents with complaints of thick, whitish, odorless, globular vaginal discharge for the past 2 weeks. On pelvic examination, the cervix appears erythematous, but there are no erosions or masses. A pap smear shows budding cells and pseudohyphae (as shown below). No dysplastic cells are present. Which of the following infectious agents is most likely to produce these findings?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The clinical features of white, curdy vaginal discharge along with pap smear showing budding cells and pseudohyphae points to vaginal candidiasis caused by Candida albicans.

  • Candidiasis is primarily caused by Candida albicans, the most prevalent fungal pathogen in humans.
  • Infections can remain superficial or disseminate systemically. Typical superficial manifestations include vaginal yeast infections and diaper rash, especially in diabetics and burn patients.
  • More severe systemic infections are often seen in individuals with catheters, peritoneal dialysis, or immunocompromise due to leukemia, chemotherapy, or transplants, which may result in sepsis or disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC).
  • C.albicans is capable of transitioning between commensal and pathogenic states. It demonstrates phenotypic switching, regulated by transcriptional controls, allowing adaptation to various host environments.
  • Host defenses rely significantly on neutrophils, macrophages, and Th17 cells. Neutrophil defects (as in NADPH oxidase disorders) heighten susceptibility.
  • Morphologically, Candida can appear as budding yeasts, pseudohyphae, or true hyphae, particularly under low oxygen.
  • Clinically, vaginal candidiasis is characterized by itching and thick, curd-like discharge and is linked to pregnancy, diabetes, or contraceptives.

Explanations of other options:

Chlamydia trachomatis (Option B): Genital infections by Chlamydia trachomatis is the most prevalent bacterial sexually transmitted infection globally. The clinical presentation of genital C. trachomatis infections include urethritis, prostatitis, epididymitis, pelvic inflammatory disease, and proctitis. Morphologically, C. trachomatis urethritis presents as a mucopurulent discharge rich in neutrophils, without visible organisms on Gram stain.

Neisseria gonorrhoeae (Option C): Neisseria gonorrhoeae is the second most common cause of bacterial sexually transmitted infections (STIs) after Chlamydia trachomatis. In males, the infection primarily causes urethritis, whereas in females, it is often silent and may lead to pelvic inflammatory disease (PID), raising the risk of infertility and ectopic pregnancy if untreated. On gram stain, it appears as gram-negative diplococci.

Trichomonas vaginalis (Option D): Trichomonas vaginalis is a large, flagellated, ovoid protozoan primarily transmitted through sexual contact. While some individuals remain asymptomatic, others may present with yellow, frothy vaginal discharge, vulvovaginal irritation, painful urination (dysuria), and discomfort during intercourse (dyspareunia). On examination, the vaginal and cervical mucosa often appears bright red with prominent cervical vessel dilation, producing the classic "strawberry cervix" appearance.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman received an abnormal pap smear report. A cervical biopsy was performed which reveals atypical squamous cells throughout the entire thickness of the epithelium as shown below. The basal membrane appears intact. What is the appropriate diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The given scenario with cervical biopsy revealing dysplasia throughout the epithelium with intact basement membrane points to a diagnosis of cervical intraepithelial neoplasia III.

  • Cervical intraepithelial neoplasia (CIN) represents precancerous changes in the cervix and has undergone evolving classification systems.
  • Initially divided into mild to severe dysplasia, the current standard simplifies the categories into low-grade squamous intraepithelial lesions (LSIL) and high-grade SIL (HSIL). CIN I corresponds to LSIL, while CIN II and III fall under HSIL.
  • The various classification systems for squamous cervical precursor lesions are given in the table below.
  • LSIL usually does not progress to invasive carcinoma and frequently regresses, while HSIL carries a higher risk of malignant transformation due to progressive HPV-driven cell cycle dysregulation.
  • LSIL reflects productive HPV infection with minimal changes in host cell proliferation, and is roughly ten times more common than HSIL.
  • Conversely, HSIL involves significant disruptions in epithelial maturation, increased proliferation, and reduced viral replication.
  • The cytologic hallmark of SIL includes nuclear enlargement, hyperchromasia, coarse chromatin, and variability in nuclear shape and size which is termed koilocytotic atypia.
  • The grading depends on the epithelial layer involved: lower third in LSIL (CIN I), upper two-thirds in HSIL (CIN II and III). (Option C ruled out)
  • When the basement membrane is invaded, it results in invasive squamous cell carcinoma which is the most common invasive cervical cancer followed by adenocarcinoma. (Options A and B ruled out)

questions.text: A 65-year-old female presented with complaints of a fungating mass arising from cervix for 2 years. Pap smear performed shows few atypical cells and presence of koilocytic cells. Biopsy taken and the histopathological image is shown below. Based on the above findings and image, what is your probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The given clinical scenario of a fungating mass arising from the cervix, pap smear showing abnormal cells, and histopathology showing keratin pearls suggests a diagnosis of invasive squamous cell carcinoma of the cervix.

  • Cervical carcinoma typically affects women between 45 and 50 years of age. The predominant histological subtype is squamous cell carcinoma, representing approximately 80% of all cases.
  • The second most common type is adenocarcinoma, which arises from adenocarcinoma in situ and accounts for about 15% of cases.
  • Cervical cancer may appear as either exophytic (fungating) or infiltrative masses.
  • Squamous cell carcinoma arises from dysplastic squamous epithelium and can be either keratinizing or nonkeratinizing as it infiltrates the cervical stroma.
  • Cervical cancer often spreads directly to nearby tissues, such as the bladder, ureters, rectum, and vagina. Advanced cases may invade lymph nodes and disseminate to distant organs like the lungs, liver, and bone marrow.
  • Superficial squamous carcinomas may be treated conservatively, but more advanced tumors require hysterectomy with lymph node dissection, radiation, and chemotherapy.
  • The outcome depends on the tumor type and stage at diagnosis.

Explanation of other options:

Adenocarcinoma (Option A): Adenocarcinoma is marked by the growth of abnormal gland-forming epithelial cells derived from the endocervix, featuring enlarged, darkly staining nuclei and cytoplasm with reduced mucin content, giving the glands a darker appearance compared to normal endocervical tissue.

Endocervical polyp (Option C): Endocervical polyps are non-cancerous, outward-growing lesions found within the endocervical canal. Their size can range from tiny sessile protrusions to larger polypoid formations that may extend through the cervical os. Microscopically, they consist of a fibrous core lined by mucus-producing endocervical glands and are frequently associated with inflammatory changes.

Trichomonas vaginalis (Option D): Trichomonas vaginalis is a flagellated, ovoid protozoan that is mainly spread via sexual transmission. Infected individuals may show no symptoms, but others can experience yellow, foamy vaginal discharge, irritation of the vulvovaginal area, pain during urination (dysuria), and painful sexual activity (dyspareunia). Clinically, the cervix and vaginal lining often exhibit a vivid red hue with dilated cervical vessels, leading to the characteristic appearance known as a "strawberry cervix."

questions.text: A 58-year-old postmenopausal female noticed a blood-tinged vaginal discharge twice during the past month. Bimanual pelvic examination shows that the uterus is normal in size, with no palpable adnexal masses. There are no cervical erosions or masses. An endometrial biopsy specimen was taken and sent for histopathological examination, image of which is shown below. Which gene is most commonly involved in this lesion among the given options?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The given clinical features of post-menopausal bleeding with histology of endometrial biopsy showing proliferative endometrial glands with minimal intervening stroma is suggestive of endometrioid endometrial carcinoma which is associated with both PTEN and PIK3CA gene mutations.

  • Endometrioid endometrial carcinoma is the most frequent type of endometrial cancer and generally arises in the setting of unopposed estrogen stimulation, often in the context of endometrial hyperplasia.
  • It typically affects perimenopausal or early postmenopausal Risk factors include obesity, diabetes, hypertension, infertility, and prolonged estrogen exposure without adequate progesterone opposition.
  • This cancer type is generally low grade and associated with PTEN, PIK3CA, ARID1A, and mismatch repair gene mutations, as well as β-catenin activation. TP53 mutations are seen in poorly differentiated cancers and occur as late events.
  • It tends to develop slowly and is often detected early due to abnormal uterine bleeding. Clinically, patients often present with abnormal uterine bleeding, which leads to early detection.
  • Grossly, the tumor may appear as a polypoid mass or as a diffuse thickening of the endometrial lining.
  • Microscopically, it resembles proliferative endometrial glands and may show back-to-back gland formation with minimal intervening stroma.
  • Depth of myometrial invasion and tumor grade are key prognostic factors.

Explanation of other options:

APC (Option D): Associated with familial adenomatous polyposis

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman had increasing abdominal enlargement for the past 6 months.On physical examination, there is abdominal distention with a fluid wave. A pelvic ultrasound scan shows bilateral cystic ovarian masses, 10 cm on the right and 7 cm on the left. The masses are surgically removed. On gross examination, the excised masses are unilocular cysts filled with clear fluid, and papillary projections extend into the central lumen of the cyst. Image of histopathological examination is shown below. Based on the above findings what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The clinical features, ovarian cysts seen bilaterally along with histopathology showing cysts lined by columnar epithelium suggests a diagnosis of serous cystadenoma.

  • Serous tumors are the most frequent malignant ovarian neoplasms and account for about 40% of all ovarian cancers.
  • These tumors arise from epithelium resembling the fallopian tube lining and can be classified as benign, borderline, or malignant.
  • Around 70% of serous tumors are benign or borderline, commonly seen between ages 20 to 45, while 30% are malignant, generally occurring later in life.
  • The benign forms like serous cystadenomas typically appear as multilocular cysts with thin walls and clear serous fluid, often bilateral, with small micropapillary projections and without epithelial thickening.
  • The precise risk factors for serous cystadenomas are unclear, but malignant serous tumors are associated with low parity, family history, and mutations in BRCA1/2 genes.
  • The cysts are lined by columnar ciliated epithelium, and in benign forms, the cells appear uniform with no atypia or stromal invasion. Serous borderline tumors show more epithelial complexity and mild nuclear atypia without stromal invasion, while serous carcinomas (high- and low-grade) display increasingly aggressive features.
  • Low-grade carcinomas may evolve from borderline tumors and typically harbor KRAS, BRAF, or ERBB2 mutations while high-grade tumors exhibit TP53 Psammoma bodies may be seen but are not specific.
  • Metastasis to peritoneum or omentum is common in malignant forms, often causing ascites.
  • Clinically, serous cystadenomas are often asymptomatic until they grow large or cause compression.

Explanation of other options:

Endometrioid tumor (Option A): Endometrioid ovarian tumors are characterized by the presence of tubular glands that closely mimic the appearance of normal or cancerous endometrial tissue, setting them apart from serous and mucinous tumors. These tumors usually show a combination of solid and cystic components.

Dysgerminoma (Option C): Dysgerminomas are typically unilateral in 80% to 90% of cases and vary widely in size, from minute nodules to large masses that can occupy most of the abdominal cavity. Grossly, they exhibit a solid, soft, and fleshy consistency with colors ranging from yellow-white to gray-pink. Microscopically, the tumor resembles seminoma and consists of large vesicular cells with clear cytoplasm, distinct cell borders, and centrally placed uniform nuclei. These cells are arranged in sheets or cords separated by sparse fibrous stroma, often infiltrated by lymphocytes and occasionally showing noncaseating granulomas.

Granulosa cell tumor (Option D): Granulosa cell tumors are typically unilateral ovarian neoplasms which often show a yellow coloration on cut surface due to the presence of intracellular lipids, especially when hormonally active. Histologically, the granulosa cells exhibit various growth patterns including cords, sheets, and strands. A hallmark feature is the presence of Call-Exner bodies which are small gland-like structures filled with eosinophilic material that resemble immature follicles.

questions.text: A 54-year-old female presented with a 3 month history of intermittent vaginal bleeding. Pelvic examination reveals a left adnexal mass. A uterine curettage shows complex endometrial hyperplasia without atypia. A CT scan of the abdomen reveals a 5 cm mass replacing the left ovary. The patient undergoes hysterectomy and bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy. Histologic examination of the ovarian mass is shown in the image. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The given clinical scenario along with histopathology showing Call-Exner bodies suggests a diagnosis of granulosa cell tumor.

  • Granulosa cell tumors are ovarian neoplasms composed of cells that mimic those of the developing granulosa layer of the ovarian follicle.
  • These tumors can occur at any age but are most frequently detected in postmenopausal women.
  • Typically unilateral, their size can vary from tiny foci to large, cystic, encapsulated masses. Hormone-producing tumors may show a yellow appearance on the cut section due to lipid accumulation.
  • Histologically, granulosa cell tumors exhibit diverse patterns. The tumor cells grow in cords, sheets, or strands. A diagnostic hallmark is the presence of Call-Exner bodies, which are gland-like spaces filled with eosinophilic material.
  • Some tumors also show a thecoma component, and luteinization may be present, with cells appearing plump and cytoplasm-rich.
  • Clinically, these tumors are important for two reasons: they often produce large quantities of estrogen and may behave as low-grade malignancies. Estrogen production can lead to precocious puberty in children and endometrial hyperplasia or carcinoma in adults.
  • Occasionally, they may produce androgens, causing virilization.
  • Inhibin, produced by granulosa cells, is elevated in these tumors and serves as a useful diagnostic and monitoring biomarker.
  • Nearly all adult-type granulosa tumors (97%) harbor FOXL2 gene mutations. This mutation is uncommon in juvenile types, implying a genetic distinction between the two.

Explanation of other options:

Dysgerminoma (Option A): Dysgerminomas are usually seen as unilateral tumors in 80% to 90% of cases, and they can range in size from barely visible nodules to large growths that fill most of the abdomen. On gross examination, they appear solid, soft, and fleshy, with a color that varies from yellow-white to gray-pink. Histologically, they resemble seminomas, being composed of large cells with clear cytoplasm, well-defined borders, and centrally located uniform nuclei. These tumor cells are arranged in cords or sheets, separated by scant fibrous stroma that is commonly infiltrated by lymphocytes and may sometimes contain noncaseating granulomas.

Serous cystadenoma (Option C): Serous cystadenomas are benign ovarian tumors that typically appear as smooth, glistening unilocular or multilocular cysts lined by columnar epithelium. They are commonly unilateral but can be bilateral in about 20% of cases and do not exhibit invasion or significant cytologic atypia. Microscopically, they retain cilia and lack stromal invasion, distinguishing them from borderline and malignant counterparts.

Sertoli-Leydig cell tumor (Option D): Sertoli-Leydig cell tumors of the ovary are typically unilateral and may grossly resemble granulosa cell tumors, with solid cut surfaces that range from gray to golden brown. Microscopically, they show variable differentiation: well-differentiated tumors contain Sertoli or Leydig cell tubules within stroma, intermediate forms show immature tubules and large eosinophilic Leydig cells, while poorly differentiated tumors display a sarcomatoid pattern with disorganized epithelial cords and may lack Leydig cells. Some tumors may also exhibit heterologous elements like mucinous glands, bone, or cartilage.

questions.text: A 43-year-old woman presents with a 6-month history of increasing abdominal girth. Physical examination reveals pronounced ascites and a left adnexal mass. A 6 cm ovarian tumor is removed. The tumor is solid and white. Histologically, it is composed of cells resembling normal ovarian stroma surrounded by collagen fibers as shown below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The given clinical features of adnexal mass along with ascites with histopathology showing well-differentiated fibroblasts and sparse intervening collagenous stroma suggests a diagnosis of fibroma.

  • Ovarian stromal tumors composed of fibroblasts (fibromas) or lipid-containing plump spindle cells with lipid droplets (thecomas) account for about 4% of all ovarian tumors. Mixed tumors with both cell types are termed fibrothecomas.
  • While thecomas and fibrothecomas may produce hormones, pure fibromas are typically non-functioning.
  • Fibromas are usually unilateral (90% of cases), solid, firm, and white-gray on cut sections, and histologically show well-differentiated fibroblasts with sparse collagenous stroma. Some may show thecal features may be present focally.
  • Clinically, these tumors often manifest as pelvic masses, sometimes painful, and are notably linked to two unusual associations: ascites, particularly when tumors exceed 6 cm and Meigs syndrome, which involves ovarian tumor, ascites, and right-sided hydrothorax.
  • Additionally, there is an association with basal cell nevus syndrome.
  • Most of these tumors are benign, but rarely, cellular fibromas showing mitosis and increased nuclear-to-cytoplasmic ratio may behave malignantly and are classified as fibrosarcomas.

Explanation of other options:

Granulosa cell tumor (Option B): Granulosa cell tumors generally occur on one side and frequently appear yellow on cut surface owing to intracellular lipid accumulation, particularly in hormonally active cases. Microscopically, these tumors display diverse architectural arrangements such as cords, sheets, and strands of granulosa cells. A distinguishing characteristic is the presence of Call-Exner bodies which are small gland-like spaces filled with pink-staining material that mimic immature ovarian follicles.

Sertoli-Leydig cell tumor (Option C): Sertoli-Leydig cell tumors usually affect only one ovary and can resemble granulosa cell tumors in appearance, featuring solid cut surfaces that vary in color from gray to golden brown. Histologically, these tumors exhibit a spectrum of differentiation: well-differentiated types display tubules formed by Sertoli or Leydig cells within a stromal background; intermediate types are composed of immature tubules along with prominent eosinophilic Leydig cells; and poorly differentiated forms have a sarcomatoid appearance with irregular epithelial cell cords and may lack Leydig cells entirely. Occasionally, these tumors may contain heterologous tissues such as mucinous glands, cartilage, or bone.

Serous cystadenoma (Option D): Serous cystadenomas are non-malignant ovarian tumors that usually present as smooth-walled, clear, single or multiloculated cysts lined by columnar epithelial cells. While often affecting one ovary, around 20% of cases may involve both. These tumors are characterized by the absence of cellular atypia or tissue invasion, and under the microscope, the lining cells often have preserved cilia with no evidence of stromal infiltration, helping to differentiate them from borderline or malignant serous tumors.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman has presented to you with complaints of cyclic abdominal pain that coincides with her menstrual cycles and attempts to become pregnant have failed over the past 5 years. There are no abnormal findings on physical examination. Laparoscopic examination shows numerous hemorrhagic 0.2-0.5 cm lesions over the peritoneal surfaces of the uterus and ovaries. Which of the following ovarian lesions is most likely to be associated with her findings?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The given clinical features along with histopathology showing both endometrial glands and stroma within the ovary suggests a diagnosis of endometrioma.

  • Endometriosis refers to the presence of endometrial tissue, including glands and stroma, at ectopic sites outside the uterus.
  • It most frequently involves the ovaries, uterine ligaments, rectovaginal septum, cul-de-sac, and pelvic peritoneum.
  • It affects about 10% of women, predominantly those in their reproductive years, especially in the third and fourth decades.
  • There are three main types: superficial peritoneal, ovarian, and deep infiltrating endometriosis. The deep form is more commonly associated with malignancy, while the superficial and ovarian types rarely transform malignantly.
  • Multiple theories explain its pathogenesis, including retrograde menstruation (regurgitation theory), vascular or lymphatic spread (benign metastasis theory), coelomic metaplasia, differentiation from stem/progenitor cells, and embryonic rests (embryologic theory).
  • Molecular mechanisms involve proinflammatory mediators, angiogenic factors like VEGF, and enzymes such as MMPs, which support implant survival and invasion. Estrogen also promotes endometriotic tissue persistence by upregulating aromatase.
  • Morphologically, endometriotic lesions appear as red-blue to yellow-brown nodules on mucosal or serosal surfaces and may cause fibrosis and adhesions.
  • Ovarian endometriosis often manifests as large cystic lesions called endometriomas or "chocolate cysts," filled with old hemorrhage.
  • Deeply infiltrating lesions can cause tissue destruction and dense adhesions.
  • Diagnosis requires the presence of both endometrial glands and stroma, though sometimes only stroma is identified.
  • Clinically, endometriosis presents with severe dysmenorrhea, dyspareunia, pelvic pain, menstrual irregularities, and infertility. Infertility is the first symptom in 30 - 40% of patients.

Explanation of other options:

Fibroma (Option A): Ovarian stromal tumors such as fibromas, thecomas, and fibrothecomas usually present with pelvic mass and are associated with ascites and Meigs syndrome (ovarian tumor, ascites, right-sided hydrothorax). Fibromas are typically unilateral, solid, gray-white, and non-functional, while thecomas and fibrothecomas may produce hormones.

Brenner tumor (Option B): Brenner tumors are usually unilateral and may appear solid or cystic and are composed of sharply outlined nests of epithelial cells resembling urothelium, often with central mucinous glands, and are set in a fibrous stroma that sometimes resembles theca cells. Most are benign, but borderline and malignant forms exist.

Krukenberg tumor (Option D): Krukenberg tumor refers to a metastatic gastrointestinal carcinoma that spreads to the ovaries, typically presenting as bilateral involvement with mucin-secreting malignant cells displaying a characteristic signet-ring morphology.

questions.text: A 50-year-old nulliparous woman with a history of diabetes has presented to the OPD with complaints of spotting throughout the entire cycle. The patient is obese and hypertensive. An ultrasound examination reveals a thickened endometrial stripe with a polypoid mass in the uterine fundus. The patient undergoes a hysterectomy and the uterus is opened to reveal a partially necrotic mass. A biopsy of the mass shows moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma. Which of the following represents the most likely precursor of this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The given clinical scenario suggests endometrial cancer for which the precursor lesion among the given options is atypical hyperplasia.

  • Endometrial hyperplasia is an abnormal proliferation of endometrial glands relative to stroma, resulting in an increased gland-to-stroma
  • It is a significant cause of abnormal uterine bleeding and a precursor to endometrioid-type endometrial carcinoma, often linked to prolonged unopposed estrogen stimulation.
  • This may result from anovulation, obesity (peripheral conversion of androgens to estrogens), menopause, estrogen-secreting tumors like granulosa cell tumors, or exogenous estrogen therapy.
  • PTEN gene inactivation is a common genetic event in both hyperplasia and endometrial carcinoma, contributing to PI3K/AKT pathway dysregulation and estrogen-dependent proliferation.
  • WHO classifies endometrial hyperplasia into two major categories: typical (non-atypical) and atypical hyperplasia (also called endometrial intraepithelial neoplasia).
  • Typical hyperplasia is characterized by variable gland sizes and shapes with intervening stroma retained. It has a low risk of progressing to carcinoma and may resolve if estrogen is withdrawn.
  • In contrast, atypical hyperplasia features crowded, back-to-back, architecturally complex glands with nuclear atypia such as vesicular chromatin and prominent nucleoli. This form overlaps histologically with well-differentiated endometrioid adenocarcinoma.
  • Carcinoma is found in up to 50% of hysterectomy specimens diagnosed with atypical hyperplasia.
  • Management includes hysterectomy for atypical hyperplasia, especially in older women or when fertility is not desired.
  • In younger women wishing to preserve fertility, progestin therapy with careful monitoring may be attempted, though lack of response often leads to surgical intervention.

Explanations of other options:

Adenomyosis (Option A): Adenomyosis is characterized by the presence of endometrial tissue within the myometrium, often signifying direct downward growth from the endometrial lining. It histologically appears as irregular clusters of endometrial stroma, with or without glands, embedded within the smooth muscle. Clinically, it presents similarly to endometriosis with symptoms such as menometrorrhagia (heavy and irregular menstruation), colicky dysmenorrhea, pain during intercourse (dyspareunia), and pelvic discomfort.

Chronic endometritis (Option C): Chronic endometritis refers to persistent inflammation of the endometrium and is often linked to underlying conditions such as chronic pelvic inflammatory disease, retained gestational tissue, intrauterine devices, and tuberculosis (especially in cases of tuberculous salpingitis). Diagnosis hinges on identifying plasma cells within the endometrial stroma, a feature not present in normal endometrium. It usually presents with symptoms like abnormal uterine bleeding, pelvic pain, vaginal discharge, or infertility.

questions.text: A 32-year-old female underwent a routine pap smear which revealed findings as shown below. Identify the condition in which the marked cells appear.
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The marked cells in the pap smear are koilocytes which are seen in human papilloma virus (HPV) infections.

  • Koilocytosis refers to a characteristic cellular change marked by nuclear atypia including enlarged nuclei, hyperchromasia, coarse chromatin granules, and variation in nuclear size and shape.
  • These nuclear abnormalities are typically surrounded by clear perinuclear vacuoles or "halos," resulting from a cytopathic effect of the HPV E5 protein.
  • Their presence is a hallmark of HPV-associated epithelial transformation.

Explanations of other options:

Normal squamous cells (Option B): The marked cells are not normal squamous cells so this option can be ruled out.

Candida (Option C): The diagnosis of candidiasis is established by detecting pseudohyphae or filamentous fungal elements in a wet mount prepared with potassium hydroxide (KOH) or on a Papanicolaou (Pap) smear.

Gardnerella vaginalis (Option D): Pap smears in gardnerella vaginalis show superficial and intermediate squamous epithelial cells enveloped by a dense layer of coccobacillary organisms.

questions.text: A 55-year-old female presented with pruritic, erythematous, and crusted raised lesions over the vulva. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The given description of the vulvar lesions along with histopathology showing the characteristic Paget cells suggests a diagnosis of Paget disease.

  • Paget disease of the vulva is a rare intraepithelial multiplication of malignant cells that resembles Paget disease of the breast and typically manifests as a red, itchy, crusted lesion resembling a map, usually affecting the labia majora.
  • It is characterized by the presence of large, malignant Paget cells within the epidermis, which may appear singly or in clusters.
  • These cells exhibit pale cytoplasm rich in mucopolysaccharides which are PAS+, Alcian blue+, and mucicarmine+ and also express cytokeratin 7.
  • They show apocrine, eccrine, and keratinocyte differentiation, likely arising from multipotent epithelial cells of vulvar skin appendages.
  • Unlike the mammary counterpart, vulvar Paget disease is rarely associated with underlying malignancy and usually remains confined to the epidermis.
  • Treatment involves wide local excision due to the lateral spread of Paget cells beyond the visible lesion.
  • Although the disease may persist for years or decades without progression, the rare occurrence of invasion is associated with poor prognosis.

Explanations of other options:

Condyloma acuminatum (Option B): Condyloma acuminatum refers to benign genital warts caused by low-risk human papillomavirus (HPV), primarily types 6 and 11. These lesions, often multiple, affect the vulva, perineal, perianal areas, and sometimes the vagina or cervix. Microscopically, they display papillary, exophytic, tree-like structures covered with thickened squamous epithelium, showing viral cytopathic features known as koilocytic atypia.

Papillary hidradenoma (Option C): Papillary hidradenoma is a well-demarcated nodule, most frequently found on the labia majora or within the interlabial folds, and may mimic carcinoma due to its tendency to ulcerate. Histologically, it resembles the intraductal papilloma of the breast, showing papillary structures lined by two distinct layers: an outer layer of columnar secretory cells and an inner layer of flattened myoepithelial cells. These features reflect its origin from sweat glands.

Lichen sclerosis (Option D): Lichen sclerosus presents as smooth, white patches or macules on the vulva that may enlarge and merge, forming a porcelain-like or parchment-like surface. When extensive, it leads to atrophy of the labia and narrowing of the vaginal opening. Histologically, it shows thinning of the epidermis, basal cell degeneration, hyperkeratosis, sclerosis of the superficial dermis, and a bandlike lymphocytic infiltrate.

questions.text: A 25-year-old pregnant female has hCG levels which are markedly high. On USG, the size of the uterus exceeds that of the corresponding gestational age and the myometrium is intact. Curettage was done and the specimen obtained is as shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Hydatidiform mole is a form of gestational trophoblastic disease characterized by abnormal trophoblastic proliferation and swollen chorionic villi.
  • It is classified into complete and partial types, with complete moles typically having a 46,XX karyotype derived entirely from paternal chromosomes, and no identifiable fetal tissue, while partial moles usually present as triploid (69,XXY) with some fetal elements.
  • Grossly, these moles resemble delicate, translucent, grape-like clusters. Microscopically, complete moles show diffuse villous enlargement with circumferential trophoblastic hyperplasia, whereas partial moles display focal villous involvement and less pronounced hyperplasia.
  • Clinically, patients often present with early pregnancy loss, elevated hCG levels disproportionately higher than normal pregnancy, and abnormal ultrasound findings.
  • These moles may lead to complications like persistent gestational trophoblastic disease or choriocarcinoma, necessitating monitoring of hCG levels post-curettage for 6-12 months to detect persistence.

Explanation of other options:

Choriocarcinoma (Option A): Choriocarcinoma is a highly aggressive malignant tumor arising from trophoblastic cells, typically following a normal or abnormal pregnancy, such as a miscarriage, ectopic pregnancy, or molar gestation. The tumor is known for its rapid spread through the bloodstream but usually responds well to chemotherapy once detected.On gross examination, it appears as a soft, yellow-white mass with areas of necrosis and hemorrhage. Microscopically, the tumor is composed solely of proliferating syncytiotrophoblasts and cytotrophoblasts without any chorionic villi. Clinically, choriocarcinoma often presents with irregular, bloody-brown vaginal discharge. It may become apparent weeks or months after a pregnancy-related event.

Invasive mole (Option C): An invasive mole is a locally aggressive form of gestational trophoblastic disease in which hydropic chorionic villi infiltrate the myometrium and may even perforate the uterine wall. It features trophoblastic proliferation and may extend into parametrial tissue and blood vessels, occasionally embolizing to distant organs like the lungs or brain, although these emboli do not metastasize or grow.

Placental site trophoblastic tumor (Option D): Placental site trophoblastic tumors (PSTTs) are rare neoplasms arise from neoplastic transformation of intermediate (extravillous) trophoblasts, which are polygonal cells that normally produce human placental lactogen. In pregnancy, these cells are found at the implantation site, in placental membranes, and within placental tissue. PSTT typically manifests as a uterine mass with either abnormal bleeding or amenorrhea and moderately increased hCG levels. Histologically, the malignant cells diffusely infiltrate the endomyometrium. PSTTs may occur after a normal pregnancy, abortion, or molar pregnancy.

questions.text: Identify the molecular subtype of breast cancer.
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The given immunohistochemical picture shows cell membrane staining which suggests a diagnosis of HER2 positive breast cancer as HER2 receptors are membrane-bound.

  • Molecular classification of breast carcinoma categorizes tumors into three major groups: luminal (predominantly estrogen receptor \ (ER)-positive and HER2-negative), HER2-enriched (mostly HER2-positive), and basal-like (triple-negative: ER-negative, PR-negative, HER2-negative).
  • This is based on gene expression profiles, with each subtype showing distinct genetic mutations, behaviors, and therapeutic responses.
  • Immunohistochemistry helps in molecular classification by identifying the ER, PR, and her2 receptor status.
  • ER and PR are nuclear receptors while HER2 receptors are located on the cell membrane so immunohistochemistry reveals staining on the respective sites.
  • Luminal A cancers are typically ER-positive, HER2-negative, and show low proliferation indices such as Ki-67. They frequently harbor PIK3CA mutations and have well-differentiated histology, including tubular, lobular, mucinous, or papillary patterns. These tumors respond well to anti-estrogen therapies and usually exhibit slow progression, long survival, and low relapse rates, often with bone metastases when recurrence occurs. (Option A ruled out)
  • Luminal B tumors, on the other hand, are also ER-positive but have high proliferation markers like Ki-67. They tend to be more aggressive, higher-grade, and are associated with a worse prognosis than Luminal A. They also respond less favorably to hormonal therapy and more often require chemotherapy. (Option B ruled out)
  • HER2-enriched tumors show amplification of the HER2 gene, are associated with TP53 mutations, and typically respond well to HER2-targeted therapies.
  • Basal-like or triple-negative breast cancers (TNBCs) lack hormone receptors and HER2 expression, are aggressive, and frequently harbor TP53 mutations. TNBCs also share features with BRCA1-associated carcinomas and show high genomic instability. (Option D ruled out)

Reference: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK583808/

questions.text: Clear cell carcinoma of ovary is classified under?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Clear cell carcinoma of the ovary is classified under epithelial cancers.

The WHO classification of ovarian tumors is given in the table given below.

Explanations of other options:

Germ cell tumors (Option A): The germ cell tumors under the WHO classification are teratoma, dysgerminoma, and yolk sac tumors.

Sex cord tumors (Option C): The ovarian sex cord stromal tumors are granulosa cell tumor, fibroma, thecoma, and fibrothecoma.

Granulosa cell tumors (Option D): It is classified under ovarian sex cord stromal tumors.

questions.text:
Which of the following are used in PAP smear?
A. Cytobrush
B. Ayres spatula
C. Speculum
D. Fixative
questions.solution:
Explanation:

All the given options are used in pap smear.

  • The Pap smear is a cytological screening method introduced by Papanicolaou that is part of routine gynecologic care and involves the examination of exfoliated cervical cells to detect premalignant and malignant lesions, particularly of the cervix.
  • Women over the age of 21 are advised to undergo regular gynecologic check-ups that include a Pap smear every three years.
  • For optimal results, the test should be performed before any vaginal examination. The patient should avoid intercourse or vaginal interventions for at least 24 hours. The ideal time for sampling is mid-cycle, around ovulation, but other times are also acceptable.
  • During the procedure, the patient lies in the dorsal position. A speculum (preferably Cusco's self-retaining) is used to expose the cervix. The squamocolumnar junction is scraped with an Ayre's spatula, and the sample is spread on a slide.
  • The slide is then fixed with 95% alcohol and stained with Pap or short stain. A fixative spray can be used in office settings.
  • There are several other tools other than Ayre's spatula available for collecting cervical cells, such as Szalay plastic spatulas in various sizes, cotton swabs (used in some centers), as well as a range of cytobrushes and broom-like devices in different shapes and dimensions.
  • Among endocervical sampling tools, the two main types are the cytobrush and the Cervex brush.
  • The cytobrush is specifically designed for sampling from the endocervical canal. It features a slender tip with fine bristles, making it easy to insert and gently collect cells from within the canal.
  • The Cervex brush, on the other hand, resembles a broom and is made of soft plastic fibers. Its central bristles are inserted into the endocervical canal, while the side bristles fan out to sweep the ectocervical surface, ensuring a comprehensive cell sample.
  • A sample is satisfactory if endocervical cells are present.

The normal cellular findings are summarised in the table below.

The following image shows the various instruments which are used in obtaining a pap smear.

Reference: https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC9063692/

questions.text:
Arrange the steps of PAP smear in correct sequence?
A. Retract vagina
B. Take smear
C. Make smear on the slide
D. Fixation
questions.solution:
Explanation:

STEPS FOR PAP SMEAR ARE

TO RETRACT WITH HELP OF LUBRICATED SPECULUM

TAKE SAMPLE

MAKE A SLIDE

FIXATION WITH 95% ETHANOL

Reference: Cytojournal. 2022; 19: 24.

questions.text: Pap smear with hyperchromatic nuclei pleomorphism with low maturation index involving almost all of the epithelial thickness. What is this called?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Dysplasia is used to describe the lesion with abnormal cellular features involving almost all of the epithelial thickness

  • Dysplasia is a premalignant change that usually affects epithelial tissues. It involves abnormal cellular features such as variation in cell size and shape (pleomorphism), darkly stained enlarged nuclei with a high nucleus-to-cytoplasm ratio, and disorganized arrangement of the epithelial structure.
  • In dysplastic squamous epithelium, the normal sequence of cell maturation from the basal layer to the surface is often interrupted or lost.
  • If the dysplasia affects the entire epithelium but the basement membrane remains intact, it is known as carcinoma in situ.

Explanation of other options:

Metaplasia (Option A): Metaplasia is an adaptive response in which one type of mature cell is replaced by another that is better equipped to endure persistent irritation or injury. This process enhances the tissue's ability to cope with environmental stress. A well-known example is Barrett esophagus, where ongoing acid exposure leads to the transformation of the normal squamous epithelium into a glandular type such as gastric or intestinal that can better resist acidic conditions. While initially protective, these metaplastic cells have the potential to progress to malignancy over time.

Hyperplasia (Option C): Hyperplasia denotes a rise in the number of cells in a particular tissue or organ, usually triggered by a defined stimulus. Unlike hypertrophy, which involves an increase in cell size, hyperplasia is characterized by cellular multiplication.

questions.text: Identify the organism shown in the Pap Smear given below.
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The given pap smear shows a wooly appearance with clubs of filamentous organism which is suggestive of Actinomycetes.

  • Actinomyces species are more commonly detected in the vaginal flora of women using intrauterine devices (IUDs), with colonization rates increasing with prolonged IUD use.
  • It may be incidentally identified in Pap smears, with studies reporting up to 7% incidence in IUD users compared to less than 1% in non-users.
  • If detected in the absence of symptoms, conservative management is usually appropriate. Options include continued observation, prolonged oral antibiotics, or IUD removal with or without subsequent antibiotic therapy.
  • However, if signs of pelvic infection or symptoms appear, the IUD should be removed and antimicrobial treatment started.

Explanation of other options:

Candida(Option A): Candida species, particularly Candida albicans, are common commensals in the vaginal flora. On a Pap smear, diagnosis is made by detecting pseudohyphae or filamentous fungal forms, which appear as branching structures. These may also be seen in a wet mount with KOH.

Gardnerella vaginalis (Option B): Gardnerella vaginalis, a gram-negative coccobacillus, is the primary pathogen associated with bacterial vaginosis. On Pap smear examination, it is identified by the presence of superficial and intermediate squamous epithelial cells that are coated with a dense, shaggy layer of coccobacilli.

Human papilloma virus (Option D): Koilocytosis is defined by distinctive changes in cells that indicate HPV infection, primarily involving abnormal nuclear features such as nuclear enlargement, dark staining (hyperchromasia), coarse chromatin texture, and irregularity in nuclear shape and size. These altered nuclei are typically encircled by clear zones or perinuclear halos.

questions.text: Findings of cervical pap smear taken during the late menstrual period from a 45-year-old lady suffering with an ovarian tumor is shown below. Which ovarian tumor is the most likely underlying cause for this finding?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The given pap smear shows large eosinophilic superficial cells instead of the basophilic basal cells expected in the post-menstrual phase, indicating the presence of an estrogen secreting tumor such as granulosa cell tumor.

  • Granulosa cell tumors are neoplasms that resemble granulosa cells of developing ovarian follicles and are classified into adult and juvenile forms, primarily based on patient age.
  • Typically unilateral, granulosa cell tumors can vary from small nodules to large solid or cystic encapsulated growths. Hormone-secreting variants often exhibit a yellow hue on cut section due to intracellular lipid content.
  • Microscopically, the tumors exhibit a wide histological range. The cells are typically cuboidal to polygonal and grow in sheets, cords, or follicle-like structures. Some may form distinctive gland-like spaces called Call-Exner bodies.
  • These tumors are significant due to two primary factors: their potential to secrete high levels of estrogen and their behavior as low-grade malignancies. In prepubertal girls, estrogen-secreting juvenile granulosa tumors may cause precocious puberty. In adult women, excess estrogen can lead to endometrial hyperplasia, breast changes, or endometrial carcinoma. A minority of tumors may produce androgens, leading to virilizing symptoms.
  • A hallmark diagnostic marker is elevated serum and tissue levels of inhibin, which aids in both diagnosis and treatment monitoring. Most adult granulosa cell tumors harbor mutations in the FOXL2 gene.

Explanation of other options:

Dysgerminoma (Option A): Dysgerminoma is the ovarian equivalent of testicular seminoma and histologically, it consists of large vesicular cells with clear cytoplasm and centrally placed nuclei, growing in sheets or cords. It is not associated with hormone secretion.

Mucinous cystadenoma (Option C): Mucinous cystadenomas are benign ovarian tumors most commonly seen in middle-aged women.These tumors are typically large, multiloculated, and filled with viscous mucin-rich fluid. Estrogen secretion is not a known feature.

Serous cystadenoma (Option D): Serous cystadenoma is commonly seen in women aged 20 - 45. Serous tumors often appear as multilocular cystic masses lined by columnar epithelium with cilia, and may project papillary structures into the cyst lumen.

questions.text: A 55-year-old female underwent hysterectomy which showed the following gross and histological features. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The given gross specimen showing well-defined gray-white nodular lesions and histopathological image showing smooth muscle cell bundles suggests a diagnosis of uterine leiomyoma.

  • Uterine leiomyoma, also referred to as fibroid, is the most prevalent tumor in women and is a benign smooth muscle neoplasm that may appear as single or multiple nodules.
  • A majority (approximately 70%) harbor MED12 gene mutations, which influence transcriptional regulation via the Mediator complex.
  • Grossly, these tumors are sharply defined, firm, gray-white, and can range from minute nodules to large pelvic masses.
  • They usually originate in the myometrium of the uterine body and may appear in intramural (within the wall), submucosal (beneath the endometrium), or subserosal (beneath the outer uterine layer) locations.
  • Histologically, they display bundles of smooth muscle cells resembling normal myometrium, with a typical oval nucleus and scant mitotic activity.
  • Although often asymptomatic, large or multiple leiomyomas may present with abnormal uterine bleeding, urinary symptoms due to bladder compression, acute pain from infarction of a large or pedunculated fibroid, and infertility.
  • During pregnancy, they can raise the risk of spontaneous abortion, fetal malposition, uterine atony, and postpartum bleeding. Malignant transformation into leiomyosarcoma is exceptionally rare.

Explanation of other options:

Carcinoma endometrium (Option A): Endometrioid carcinoma may present as either a polypoid mass or a diffuse lesion involving the endometrial lining, with spread typically occurring through myometrial invasion and extension into adjacent pelvic structures. Histologically, it exhibits glandular architecture and is graded based on differentiation.

Malignant mixed Mullerian tumor (Option C): Carcinosarcoma, also known as malignant mixed Mullerian tumor (MMMT), is a biphasic neoplasm that contains both malignant epithelial (carcinomatous) and mesenchymal (sarcomatous) components. Grossly, the tumor is often bulky, polypoidal, hemorrhagic, and may fill the uterine cavity with deep myometrial invasion, occasionally protruding into the cervix or vagina. Microscopically, it shows adenocarcinomatous epithelium (serous, endometrioid, clear cell, mucinous, etc.) mixed with mesenchymal tissue that can be homologous (resembling uterine stroma or smooth muscle) or heterologous (like rhabdomyosarcoma or chondrosarcoma).

Endometriosis (Option D): Endometriotic lesions often appear as red-blue to yellow-brown nodules due to cyclic bleeding and are frequently associated with adhesions and fibrosis, especially in widespread disease. Histologically, diagnosis is confirmed by the presence of both endometrial glands and stroma.

questions.text: A 35-year-old female with adnexal mass, CA 125 normal, LDH raised and CA 19.9 was normal. Gross and histopathology has been given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The given clinical features along with histology showing large vesicular cells separated by fibrous septa rich in lymphocytes points to a diagnosis of dysgerminoma.

  • Dysgerminoma is the ovarian counterpart of testicular seminoma and is the most common malignant ovarian germ cell tumor, accounting for about half of such cases.
  • Though it can be seen at any age, it predominantly occurs in the second and third decades of life and may be associated with gonadal dysgenesis, including cases of pseudohermaphroditism.
  • Most of these tumors do not produce hormones, though a minority may show elevated chorionic gonadotropin due to the presence of syncytiotrophoblastic cells.
  • They express stem cell markers like OCT3, OCT4, and NANOG and frequently show KIT gene expression, with about one-third harboring activating mutations in this gene, making KIT a potential therapeutic target.
  • Morphologically, most dysgerminomas are unilateral and can vary greatly in size, from small nodules to large masses that occupy the abdominal cavity.
  • On gross examination, they appear solid, soft, and yellow-white to gray-pink.
  • Microscopically, they resemble seminomas and are composed of large vesicular cells with clear cytoplasm, distinct cell borders, and central nuclei.
  • These tumor cells grow in nests or cords separated by delicate fibrous stroma infiltrated by lymphocytes and sometimes noncaseating granulomas. Occasionally, dysgerminoma nodules may be found in benign cystic teratomas, or vice versa.

Explanation of other options:

Yolk sac tumor (Option A): The hallmark histologic feature is the Schiller-Duval body, a glomeruloid structure with a central blood vessel surrounded by tumor cells in a cystic space also lined by tumor cells. Additionally, these tumors often contain hyaline droplets, both intracellular and extracellular, which frequently test positive for α-fetoprotein.

Mature teratoma (Option C): Mature (benign) teratomas are typically unilocular cystic lesions that may contain sebaceous material, hair, and even teeth or calcifications, with a cyst wall lined by squamous epithelium and adnexal structures. Microscopically, they contain well-differentiated derivatives from all three germ layers such as cartilage, bone, thyroid, and neural tissue.

Serous cystadenoma (Option D): Serous cystadenomas usually appear as multilocular cysts lined by papillary epithelium within fibrous walls or as masses on the ovarian surface. Microscopically, they display columnar epithelium with retained cilia and occasional microscopic papillae.

questions.text: A 25-year-old female patient presented with complaints of feeling of mass per abdomen. On examination, a mass was found on the left adnexal region with multiple solid and cystic areas. The patient was operated and the mass was removed and is shown below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The given clinical scenario of an ovarian mass in a post-pubertal female with well-differentiated unilocular cyst suggests a diagnosis of dermoid cyst.

  • Teratomas are germ cell tumors classified into three types: mature (benign), immature (malignant), and monodermal or specialized variants.
  • Mature teratomas, also known as dermoid cysts, are commonly unilateral but may be bilateral in 10 -15% of cases.
  • They typically appear as unilocular cysts filled with hair and sebaceous material, lined by a thin, gray-white, wrinkled epidermal wall, often showing hair shafts, calcifications, and even recognizable tooth structures.
  • Microscopically, the wall is composed of stratified squamous epithelium with sebaceous glands and adnexal structures. Other elements from all three germ layers such as cartilage, bone, thyroid, and neural tissue are frequently present.

Explanation of other options:

Serous cystadenoma (Option B): Serous cystadenomas commonly present as multicystic lesions with fibrous walls lined by papillary epithelium or as surface projections on the ovary.

Granulosa cell tumor (Option C): Granulosa cell tumors are typically unilateral and can range from small microscopic foci to large, solid, or cystic encapsulated masses. Tumors with hormonal activity often appear yellow due to lipid accumulation.

Dysgerminoma (Option D): Dysgerminomas are usually unilateral tumors that range from small nodules to large masses and have a soft, fleshy appearance with a yellow-white to gray-pink cut surface.

questions.text: WHAT DOES THIS INSTRUMENTS HELP IN
questions.solution:
Explanation:

(a) Cotton swabs for collection of smear from the transformation zone,

(b) Ayer's spatula,

(c) Szalay's spatula of different sizes.

(d) Cytobrush,

(e) Cervex brush.

Reference: Cytojournal. 2022; 19: 24.
